hi @marko-p thanks for the contribution. I was just looking at the docs and it says that pool is optional http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html#createFloatingIP please can you extend the logic to support pool as an optional argument, this will also support existing users of the method.

yeah!!
@tonybaloney finally :dancers:
Merged. Thanks @jetbird it might be time to get a Python editor with a built in linter! Try Komodo or Atom :-)

@tonybaloney Thanks for the help and support :+1: I am using pycharm and flake8 is not working ok. I installed pylint via pip. I will be contributing again, so please if you can give me your email address would be great :)

Thanks for such a quick reply! The pool is optional only if there is only one pool available. I made the ip_pool attribute optional, but in case there are more than one IP pools available, not providing the ip_pool will return None - without printing anything. I'm not sure this is the correct way to handle this, because I did not read the whole guideline for contributing to libcloud (sorry!), I just looked up other functions in the same file.
One more note, I don't have an option to test my code against an Openstack tenant with only one floating IP pool.

I modified your suggestion a bit in order to follow the guideline to [use "is not None" when checking if a variable is provided or defined](https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/development.html#prefer-to-use-is-not-none-when-checking-if-a-variable-is-provided-or-defined)

<s>Again, this code raises an exception in case the user does not provide the pool name and there are more than one pools available. Is that ok?</s> Forget that, I've read your answer about what assumption you are talking about :)
perfect. I think this behavior is correct since the error states what the issue is. Merging

Hi @Kami, the new patch declares the arguments explicitly.

Excellent contribution thanks @jadunham1

As mentioned in the PR description, I have introduced a new `get_regions` driver class method in 04dbe1891f7e3c90c5f5890f67d4f41c54f3a23b (other related changes - 2b2a79ccedefaf584beb463ac371f3d07e3e1f97, 3cb03ebb0d65854924b4866debed858f2b493e40).

This approach is not ideal since we already have `list_locations` methid, but the problem is `list_locations` tends to be user account specific (connection needs to be established to retrieve locations which are available for that particular user account) while `list_regions` returns global regions which tend to be the same for all the users (and this region argument is passed to the driver constructor before the connection to the provider is established).

In short - this means we now have two concepts - location and region. Ideally we could some how unify this into a single concept (if that's even possible).

I'm open to feedback and suggestions.

IMO @Kami it doesn't make sense to consolidate the regions and locations. Most of the providers follow a hub and spoke type system, Amazon does with AZ's for example, which tie to the APIs. The 'location' is the data center and the 'region' is the geographic region, including isolated environments, like the fed-gov cloud.
I think what we have here is good.

The only change I would make it to turn the region into a class or a tuple. the region code, the location and a description string. e.g. return ['syd', 'Sydney, Australia', 'Australia public instance')... instead of ['syd'].
I quickly glanced over salt cloud code and it seems that drivers which use libcloud already use `region` argument so it should be fine.

Thanks for the review @tonybaloney.
I have added a comment explaining the rational behind the exception ignorance.
Reviewed final changes. :+1: I will update other drivers with list_regions as a separate PR

I see you made no changes to the `libcloud.utils.security` module. What's our plan for that module?

Do we plan to remove and deprecate it or do we plan to keep it for backward compatibility reasons (this mostly means making sure `VERIFY_SSL_CERT`, `SSL_VERSION` and `CA_CERT_PATH` module level constants are still respected)?

@jetbird I also noticed you don't have your git name and email fully configured.

Please follow the instructions at https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-First-Time-Git-Setup and configure your git name and email. This way it's easier for us to track commits back to actual contributors.

Are the types already sorted for other APIs (compute, loadbalancer, storage)? If not, we should do it there as well to keep it consistent.

As far as existing order goes - we sorted providers based on the date they were added (from oldest to the newest).
Have already tested. Merging

You're right @Kami , they are not already sorted for the other providers, so we should do it.

The issue I've found with the oldest-to-newest ordering is that it makes it slightly more complicated when adding in-progress drivers to the codebase, because each new in-progress driver is guaranteed to introduce a Git merge conflict with all the other in-progress drivers. With alphabetical sorting, merge conflicts could still arise, but at least they won't happen every single time.
@Kami I improved a bit the implementatino of the IP type resolution and updated tests accordingly.

@Kami I don't know how to add tests for this fix because I need to check the body of the request but all tests seems to test the reply.

To test the body of the request I have to do it in `OpenStackIdentity_3_0_MockHttp` which is not a subclass of `unittest.TestCase` and doesn't have the `assert...` methods.

Thanks.

Please also add a comment to each doc string class otherwise things will get out-of-sync soon :)

Ideally this would also be auto-sorted on commit, but comment is fine to start with.

I merged this change into trunk.

Please follow up with tests as soon as you can.
